Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Water Management At An Early Urban Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The provision of a dependable water supply is of critical importance to human societies both today and in the past. Dr. Nicholas Dunning and Mr. Jeffrey Brewer of the University of Cincinnati, along with an interdisciplinary research group, consisting of colleagues from the U.S., Mexico, and Canada, will study the development and maintenance of an urbanized, complex system of water collection, storage, and distribution within an area of limited and ephemeral natural water resources in the heart of the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico. Previous studies on water management have identified and analyzed a variety of water management features within the context of regional environmental and cultural changes. Adapting to variable climatic conditions and expressing political control, in particular, are considered key considerations in the creation and oversight of water storage features. Archaeology is well positioned to provide unique insight into this discussion by focusing on the complex interrelationship between hydrology, topography, vegetation, and architecture across multiple spatial and temporal scales. When and how do carefully managed water resources become an inherent component of urban adaptation? Although the nature and scale of a community's water features change across space and time, understanding the relationship between water storage, climatic conditions, and human settlement is vital to promoting sustainability, resource conservation, and public education in global societies.

Dr. Dunning, Mr. Brewer and colleagues will use empirical data to study how residents of both the urban core and urban periphery managed their limited water resources and developed and maintained a complex system of water management. The research will be conducted at the ancient Maya site of Yaxnohcah, located within the central lowlands of the Yucatan Peninsula. This site provides a unique opportunity to advance understanding of critical resource management and utilization practices that permitted the local inhabitants to support a high population density across a long span of time. The researchers will work with a team of archaeologists, geographers, and environmental scientists to examine the area's hydrological, ecological, and land use history from the Middle Preclassic to Early Postclassic periods (900 B.C. - A.D. 1100). The combination of archaeological excavation, sediment core studies, and high-resolution satellite imagery analysis will permit a unique examination of this civilization's hydraulic developments and advance the field in new directions. This diverse multidisciplinary dataset will enable a more complete understanding of the physical, temporal, and spatial characteristics of these hydraulic features and their precise roles in the daily lives and activities of community inhabitants. This research will advance our broader understanding of the resilient capacity of human societies faced with significant environmental challenges, and the collaborative focus of the project will also establish and enrich opportunities for international student training and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Outcomes Report (2017) on Award 1519015

Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ancient Maya Water Management at the Early Urban Center of Yaxnohcah, Campeche, Mexico

PI: Nicholas Dunning; co-PI: Jeffrey Brewer

The need to secure a safe and dependable water supply has been a driving force in human culture for millennia, and is a problem that is increasing in the world today as population numbers soar and water sources decline due to overuse and contamination.  Ancient Maya Civilization reached its zenith in a region, the Elevated Interior Region (EIR) of the Yucatan Peninsula, with extreme water-related challenges: a seasonal precipitation regime including a 5/6-month dry season, and a karst environment with very few natural perennial water sources. The ancient Maya city of Yaxnohcah, located within the EIR (figure 1), provides an ideal test case for studying how residents of this early, important Maya center managed their crucial, and ephemeral, water resources; when and how water reservoirs (aguadas) became a component of urban design; and the degree to which these aguadas were interconnected as a unified hydraulic system for the conservation of a scarce resource, along with household-scale water collection features (tanks).  Our investigations utilized GIS-enabled spatial and hydrological analyses to select reservoirs and household tanks for excavation. Construction of the project GIS (geographic information system) benefitted enormously from previously obtained (2014) lidar (light detection and ranging) imagery of the 25 square kilometer area centered on central Yaxnohcah, which provided a digital elevation model (DEM) revealing the extent and form of the ancient city essentially stripped of its masking tropical forest vegetation (figure 2).  This imagery revealed previously unknown urban reservoirs as well as thousands of small depressions, some of which we believed likely to be household water tanks.

Excavations in 2015 and 2016 revealed that civic-scale reservoirs were constructed as a fundamental part of Yaxnohcah’s urban design, with the paved surfaces created by monumental architecture delivering rainwater runoff into large reservoirs constructed in adjacent, low-lying terrain. The Brisa Reservoir is one of the largest and earliest reservoirs thus far identified in the Maya Lowlands, having been constructed between 800 and 700 BCE (figure 3).  Excavations in the Fidelia Reservoir indicate that water-collection and storage technology became more sophisticated and efficient over time.  Our excavations in household tanks revealed that the ancient Maya were simultaneously investing in and developing water collection and storage technology that was managed by the occupants of individual residential groups. Test excavations conducted within these residential features were necessary to determine the presence and nature of culturally-modified surfaces that would have functioned as water retention seals at the base of the tanks (figure 4). Importantly, despite presenting similar physical profiles in the lidar and on the ground, not all investigated depressions contained either a plaster or clay “floor” and appear to be unmodified natural features or quarries (figure 5). In essence, the ancient Maya learned to harvest rain during those months of each year when nature provided this vital resource and to store it in sufficient quantities to survive the annual dry season.  On the Yucatan Peninsula today, deep wells (not possible in the pre-Hispanic past) tap into subterranean aquifers to fulfill the needs of the region’s rapidly growing population and provide water for agricultural irrigation. However, these groundwater resources are already being depleted, as water is being used at rates faster than natural recharge.  Many modern water needs could be met instead by re-investing in the rain harvesting technologies that were developed by the ancient Maya, whose descendants comprise much of the region’s population.

Our investigations took place within the framework of a larger, multi-national archaeological project, the Proyecto Arqueologica Yaxnohcah, with professional staff and students from several US, Canadian, and Mexican universities collaborating in a long-term research endeavor attempting to elicit the development of this formative Maya city. The data we produced is being published and presented in its own right, but also being integrated into the efforts and products of the larger project.  NSF funding provided the bulk of the financial support for our portion of the project research in 2015 and 2016.  Output to date has included co-PI Jeffrey Brewer’s successful completion of his doctoral dissertation and completion of his PhD in geography at the University of Cincinnati (April 2017), publication of one professional article (1), several professional presentations, with additional publications, and public website displays in review, preparation, or planned for the near future.

1.  Brewer, J. L., C. Carr, N. P. Dunning, D. Walker, A. Anaya Hernandez, M. Peuramaki-Brown, and K. Reese-Taylor. 2017. Employing airborne lidar and archaeological testing to determine the role of small depressions in water management at the ancient Maya site of Yaxnohcah, Campeche, Mexico. Journal of Archaeological Science Reports 13: 291-302.
